title: R43984
content: Songwriters and recording artists are entitled to payment for reproductions and performances of their music. However, they do not have total control over their music. For example, Taylor Swift can withdraw her own recorded music from Spotify as a singer who owns the rights to her sound recordings, but she cannot dictate how the service uses other recorded versions of her musical works. Ryan Adams was able to cover her album 1989 on Spotify under certain conditions and paying Swift a royalty. Taylor Swift, as a singer who owns the rights to her sound recordings, can withdraw her music from Spotify but cannot control how the service uses other versions of her songs. The payment she receives for her music depends on market forces, contracts, and copyright laws. Congress updated copyright laws in the 1990s to address music distribution on the internet, aiming to balance combating piracy and protecting revenue sources in the music industry. The evolution of music distribution has seen a shift towards digital services, blurring traditional lines of exploitation. In 1999, recording industry revenues peaked at $21.3 billion, coinciding with the introduction of Napster. Apple's iTunes Music Store in 2003 provided a legal option for purchasing songs online. By 2012, digital downloads surpassed physical media sales, with Apple dominating the market. After dominating the market with digital music downloads, Apple faced declining sales as streaming services like Spotify gained popularity. To combat this, Apple launched Apple Music in 2015. The rise of subscription music services has significantly changed music consumption patterns, with streaming services accounting for a large portion of total U.S. recording industry retail spending. Despite some growth in consumer spending on music in recent years, it remains significantly below its 1999 peak. Consumer spending on music in the U.S. grew 14% between 2016 and 2017 but remains nearly two-thirds below its 1999 peak. This shift in consumption patterns impacts how creators and music industry professionals are compensated for their work under copyright law. The Music Modernization Act, passed by the House of Representatives in April 2018, aims to streamline the licensing process for digital music services.
